last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1874486
>lube derailleur
Hold up a second now. What's happening in your pic, is fucking nonsense. You're not going to be able to helpfully lubricate a jockey wheel without unbolting the cage. Dropping oil on it there is going to have the sole effect of attracting more dirt/grime onto them.

You lubricate your -chain- when it needs it, and you can scrape gunk off your jockey wheels poorly when you do that.

The proper service is done when you install a new chain, then you can take the derailer cage apart and properly clean/lubricate the internal parts of the jockey wheels.

Likewise for lubricating the pivots of your derailer. It's likely unnecessary and will likely only whick dirt/grime into hem.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1874496
>lube chain
>chain carries lube to jockeys
what's the difference? also its dry lube anyways

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1874504
The difference is that you WANT the lube to be inside your chain, NOT on the jockey wheel.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
There is a counterintuitive idea in road systems where a shortcut slows down the whole system, as any one car has no incentive to go a longer route, but if the shortcut is closed most peoples travel time will be decreased.
The same is probably true of transit systems, but is probably harder to observe, predict and model. The slowdowns are probably in transfers being slowed down by congested hallways ect.
Also when do you have too many lines? When you don't have the money to run them at good frequencies. Could you close a line and increase the frequency on other lines?
This is the logic of many small city bus systems, where there are too many bus routes, but non of them are frequent enough to be useful. Spending the same money on fewer routes would bring better service to the whole system and possibly make it self-sufficient.

So I've learned another reason why they're not popular: they really, really do not tolerate crosschaining. Like half my cassette is unbearable to ride in when I'm in the small ring. They do make it a lot easier to stay in the big ring while climbing, so that somewhat makes up for the annoyance, but round chainrings are definitely not a conspiracy to make you slow.

I personally look a lot at how well rail competes with road when I gauge the success of rail freight, because a punctual, reliable and commercially viable rail freight system attracts a lot of goods that otherwise would be shipped by road. Did you do the math? graf zeppelin ii carried 70 passengers and 40 crew members, and used 65000kg of diesel fuel (so 79000l) for a 16500km range. That's around 479 liters spent every 100 km, or a 6.84 l/100km fuel consumption per passenger - which sounds high compared to current aircraft (2.27 to 3.76 l/100km), but that fails to consider that every passenger had it's own cabin while modern airlines try to cram as many people as possible for a given payload.

Using the 787 as a reference, that can carry a maximum of 440 people for a 57277 kg payload - as the graf zeppelin ii can carry a 37000 kg payload, that would mean that given the same passenger density it would have 284 seats, and consume 1,69 l/100km per passenger. Argue all you want that you can't cram that many people in trips that take days instead of hours, but that still means that 1930's technology beats any new passenger plane in terms of raw fuel efficiency...

Once again, airships have quite a few problems (travel time, construction costs, lack of climb ability, sheer size), but fuel consumption isn't one of them.

>>1869158
The range these airships have compared to the amount of fuel they carry already indicates they were working rather efficiently.>>1862751

If you do the math, you'll also see that at top speed (thus peak inneficiency) the graf zeppelin ii needa 3,56 Mw of power to attain 135 km/h, which amounts to around 78 kn of thrust or 7600 kgf if you assume a propeller efficiency of 80%.

Compare that to 232 000 kg of gross lift, and it adds up to a 30:1 lift to drag ratio. Given the way parasitic drag works, going twice as fast would reduce it to a 7:1, but at half speed it improves to 120:1, so airships are fuel efficient within their operating speeds even by modern standards.

skate shoes and bike shoes are pretty much opposites. skate shoes have a lot of padding and a thin, flexible sole for "boardfeel". they can also have reinforced toe area and stiffness/material around the ankle for support. bike shoes don't have as much padding, and have a stiffer sole to support the foot and make better power transfer when pedaling.
